security_audit.summary: This is an official Anthropic skill containing documentation and guidance for building MCP servers. The skill consists of markdown documentation files and Python evaluation scripts. No malicious patterns detected. The Python scripts are standard evaluation harnesses for testing MCP servers.

content.user_title: Build MCP Servers for LLM Integration
content.value_statement: Creating MCP servers requires knowledge of protocols, tool design, and best practices. This skill provides complete guidance for building high-quality MCP servers in Python or TypeScript.
actual_capabilities: Provides step-by-step workflow for MCP server development from research to testing
Includes TypeScript and Python implementation guides with code examples
Offers tool naming conventions and input schema patterns using Zod and Pydantic
Contains evaluation harness scripts for testing MCP server quality
Documents best practices for error handling, pagination, and response formats
Covers transport options including stdio and streamable HTTP
limitations: This skill provides guidance only. It does not generate complete MCP servers automatically.
You must have basic programming knowledge in Python or TypeScript.
External API credentials and access are required for actual integrations.
The evaluation scripts require the Anthropic API key to run tests.

use_cases.title: Create API Integration Server
use_cases.description: Build an MCP server that wraps your company API. Enable Claude to query data, create records, and perform actions through well-designed tools.

use_cases.title: Build Infrastructure Tools
use_cases.description: Create MCP tools for cloud services and deployment pipelines. Allow Claude to check status, trigger builds, and manage resources.

use_cases.title: Design Tool Schemas
use_cases.description: Use the best practices guide to design tool schemas with proper validation. Ensure your MCP server follows naming conventions and error handling standards.

output_examples.input: Create an MCP tool for searching GitHub issues
output: Input parameters: query (string), repo (string), state (open/closed), limit (1-100), offset (number)
Response includes: total count, current page items, has_more flag, next_offset value
Error handling: 404 for invalid repo, 403 for permission denied, 429 for rate limit

best_practices: Use service prefix in tool names to avoid conflicts. Example: github_create_issue instead of create_issue.
Return pagination metadata (has_more, next_offset, total_count) for all list operations.
Provide actionable error messages that guide the LLM toward solutions.
anti_patterns: Do not create tools that return unbounded data. Always implement limits and pagination.
Do not use generic tool names like send_message. Include service context in names.
Do not expose raw API errors. Transform them into clear messages with next steps.

faq.question: What programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: TypeScript (recommended) and Python. TypeScript has better SDK support and type safety. Python uses FastMCP framework.

faq.question: What transport should I use for my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use stdio for local tools and command-line integration. Use streamable HTTP for remote servers and multi-client scenarios.

faq.question: How do I validate tool inputs?
faq.answer: Use Zod schemas in TypeScript or Pydantic models in Python. Both provide runtime validation with clear error messages.

faq.question: How many tools should my MCP server have?
faq.answer: Focus on comprehensive API coverage. Start with the most common operations. Balance between endpoint coverage and workflow tools.

faq.question: How do I test my MCP server?
faq.answer: Use the included evaluation harness. Create 10 complex questions that require multiple tool calls. Run with the evaluation.py script.

faq.question: What is the tool naming convention?
faq.answer: Use snake_case with service prefix. Format: service_action_resource. Examples: github_create_issue, slack_send_message.
